subject: Ethics
title: Henrietta Lacks and Research Ethics
description: A quick win: understand Henrietta Lacks and Research Ethics.

hook.text: Her cells have been to space, helped cure polio, and are in labs worldwide. She never gave permission.

buildup.text: In 1951, doctors took Henrietta Lacks' cancer cells without consent. They called them HeLa cells.

discovery.text: HeLa cells were the first to survive and multiply in a labâ€”revolutionizing medical research forever.

twist.text: Her family lived in poverty while companies sold her cells for profit. Nobody told them for decades.

climax.text: Her story forced a reckoning: who owns human tissue, and what do we owe research subjects?

punchline.text: Science advanced. Consent didn't. That was the real disease.

quiz.question: What ethical issue does the Henrietta Lacks case highlight?
options: Taking and profiting from human tissue without consent
The need for more funding in biology
